bibl.title: Letter from Fred L. Soper to Philip Showalter Hench, March 6, 1953

div1.p: Soper has proposed to the Delta Omega Public Health Fraternity that a volume including articles by Finlay, Reed, and Gorgas be published. He believes that such a work would help alleviate nationalistic tensions.

div1.head: Letter from Fred L. Soper to Philip Showalter Hench, March 6, 1953
div1.opener:
OFICINA SANITARIA PAN AMERICAN
WASHINGTON
D
PAN AMERICAN SANITARY BUREAU
Regional Office of the
WORLD HEALTH ORGANIZATION
WASHINGTON, D. C.
CABLE ADDRESS: OFSANPAN
6 March 1953
Dr. Philip Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
At long last, please accept my sincere congratulations
on your work on cortizone and everything that has followed.

I regretted very much not being able to be present for
the Cuban-United States celebration on December 3, but for-
tunately have had an opportunity to see the notes which you
forwarded to General Love. It was indeed a pleasure to see
your notes on the way in which there is gradually coming to
be a mutual recognition of the contributions made by Cuban
and U.S. workers. Earlier in the year, at the Inter-American
Congress of Hygiene in Havana, we had a rather extensive dis-
cussion of yellow fever with a talk by Dr. Recio on the work
by Finlay without engendering any animosities.

At the annual meeting of the Delta Omega Public Health
Fraternity some months ago, it was proposed that the Fraternity
should continue with its program of republication of medical
and public health classics. When suggestions were being made,
I proposed that a volume should be prepared covering the early
work in yellow fever, more specifically, selected portions of
Finlay publications together with those of Walter Reed and
possibly others of that epoch. I am thinking particularly of
Gorgas. It was my suggestion that such a volume bringing
together the works with adequate translations, would do much
to alleviate friction on nationalistic grounds. The sugges-
tion was rather favorably received but nothing has been done
to carry out the project. The financial resources of the
Fraternity are not very great but funds can probably be found
if we get the editorial work, selection and translation carried
out.

If you have any suggestions regarding this matter, I
would appreciate getting them. I would also appreciate having
-2-
in my files a copy of your notes of the December visit to
Cuba if you can conveniently supply them and would care to
do so.

May I suggest that you put the Pan American Sanitary
Bureau on your list of visits on your next trip to Washing-
ton.
With kindest personal regards, I remain
